Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, \u00a.proposition: Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides in pertinent part that any lessor or landlord who “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant” shall be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, together with costs and reasonable attorneys’ fees.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19..proposition: The amount in controversy is $2,000, exclusive of interest, costs, and any attorneys’ fees permitted by statute or common law, which is within the jurisdictional limits of this Court. See G.L. c. 218, § 19.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 2, 8..proposition: Venue is proper in the Cambridge Division of the District Court Department because the Premises are located in Cambridge, Middlesex County, and the cause of action arose there. See G.L. c. 223, §§ 2, 8.

G.L. c. 186..proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been the owner, landlord, and/or person entitled to receive rent for the Premises within the meaning of G.L. c. 186.

Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mas.raw_text: Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375 (1942)
Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mas.proposition: As a matter of Massachusetts common law and statute, every residential lease and tenancy-at-will includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment guaranteeing that the tenant’s possession of the premises will not be substantially interfered with by the acts or omissions of the landlord or those acting under the landlord’s authority. See G.L. c. 186, § 14; Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375 (1942); Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977).
Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly characterizes eviction as a contract-based defense grounded in an implied warranty of quiet enjoyment in every lease. The court states that the landlord “impliedly warrants the quiet enjoyment of the demised premises” and ties constructive eviction to a substantial deprivation of use and enjoyment by the landlord’s acts or omissions. While it does not cite G.L. c. 186, § 14, it clearly affirms the common-law implied covenant of quiet enjoyment applicable to residential leases, matching the proposition in substance.
Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The defence of eviction, actual or constructive, is based upon a failure of consideration, or a breach, whether of commission or omission, of a covenant of the lease so material as to excuse the tenant from performing. … It is a defence sounding in contract since the landlord impliedly warrants the quiet enjoyment of the demised premises, Ellis v. Welch, 6 Mass. 246, 250; Duncklee v. Webber, 151 Mass. 408; Brown v. Holyoke Water Power Co. 152 Mass. 463; Case v. Minot, 158 Mass. 577, 585; 3 Williston, Contracts (Rev. ed.) § 891 ….”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: As a matter of Massachusetts common law and statute, every residential lease and tenancy-at-will includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment guaranteeing that the tenant’s possession of the premises will not be substantially interfered with by the acts or omissions of the landlord or those acting under the landlord’s authority. See G.L. c. 186, § 14; Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375 (1942); Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely treats the covenant of quiet enjoyment as an implied term in the residential leases and analyzes whether the landlord’s acts and omissions (including failure to control a lounge tenant) that substantially interfered with the tenants’ use and occupancy violated that covenant. The court explicitly states that a landlord breaches the covenant when substantial interference with possession is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done—without requiring proof of subjective intent—thereby supporting the proposition as to Massachusetts common law (and fitting with the statutory formulation in G.L. c. 186, § 14).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential tenancy and prohibits the landlord from substantially interfering with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the leased premises by acts or omissions under the landlord’s control. See Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375 (1942); Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that every tenancy includes an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb the tenant’s quiet enjoyment, and it describes this right as freedom from serious interferences with the tenancy caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions. It then relies on Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott and related cases to explain that liability arises when the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s conduct is interference with the tenant’s rights, which aligns with the proposition that substantial interference due to acts or omissions under the landlord’s control breaches the implied covenant. Although the case involves statutory G.L. c. 186, § 14 as well, the Court clearly reaffirms the common-law implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in residential tenancies and its scope.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. Although early cases applying the covenant of quiet enjoyment required intent on the part of the landlord … more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights. Westland Hous. Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375, 381-383 (1942).”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284–286 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: A landlord may be liable for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where the landlord’s acts or omissions, or those of persons acting under the landlord’s authority, create substantial and ongoing disturbances that significantly impair the tenant’s use of the premises, even if the landlord did not specifically intend the disturbance. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716–718 (1977) (landlord liable where he created conditions leading to recurring noise from adjacent lounge); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284–286 (1994) (landlord liable where failure to act allowed continuing interference).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord can be liable under the covenant of quiet enjoyment based on serious, ongoing interference arising from third-party drug activity in common areas when the landlord fails to take reasonable steps to address it. The court emphasizes that liability turns on the natural and probable consequences of what the landlord did or failed to do, not on intent, and remands for fact-finding on whether the landlord’s omissions permitted the continuing interference. This directly supports the proposition that substantial disturbances caused or allowed by the landlord’s acts or omissions can breach quiet enjoyment even absent specific intent.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy… In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions. Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716 (1977). Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’… If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982) (rescript)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: A substantial and unreasonable level of noise, dust, or other construction-related disturbance emanating from another part of a landlord’s property, when allowed to persist for a significant period and materially affecting the tenant’s ability to use the premises as a residence, constitutes an indirect interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982) (rescript) (affirming tenant relief where landlord’s acts caused substantial interference).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns failure to provide heat and resulting breach of quiet enjoyment; it does not involve construction-related disturbances, noise, dust, or activity emanating from another part of the landlord’s property. The quoted language about quiet enjoyment (relying on Blackett and Simon) is general and not tied to construction-type interference. Thus, Lowery supports the broader rule that substantial interference with habitability (here, lack of heat) violates G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it does not specifically support the construction‑disturbance proposition for which it is cited.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’…and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See generally Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715-716 (1977), and cases cited.… [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’… On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to…a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 788–789 (1994)
Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: The protections of G.L. c. 186, § 14, apply broadly and are construed liberally in favor of tenants. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–106 (1982) (statute to be read in light of remedial housing policy); Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 788–789 (1994) (quiet enjoyment provisions part of extensive tenant-protective scheme).
Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The opinion does not expressly state that G.L. c. 186, § 14 must be construed ‘liberally’ in favor of tenants, but it does treat § 14 as part of a tenant-protective framework and applies it in a way that eases the tenant’s burden (recognizing negligent omissions as sufficient for liability, not just recklessness). The court emphasizes that landlord omissions that foreseeably impair the value of the premises violate § 14 and awards attorney’s fees on that basis. This supports characterizing the quiet enjoyment provisions as components of a broader tenant-protective remedial scheme, though the ‘liberally construed’ phrasing comes more directly from Simon v. Solomon than from Cruz itself.
Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: “Decisions from this court and from the Appeals Court clearly support the imposition of civil liability under § 14 in circumstances like those present in this case. In Ianello v. Court Management Corp., 400 Mass. 321, 323 (1987), it was said that a landlord violates § 14 when his acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises… A landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.… A ‘landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’”

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 760–761 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff is entitled to recover her actual and consequential damages, or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, together with costs and reasonable attorneys’ fees. See also Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 760–761 (1979) (discussing remedial nature of § 14); Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. at 788–789.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion directly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 and states the statute’s remedial scheme: a landlord who violates § 14 is liable for "actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee." The court applies this to reject a per‑month multiplier and explains that when actual damages exceed three months’ rent, actual damages are the measure of recovery, confirming the proposition’s description of the remedy and inclusion of costs and reasonable attorney’s fees.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: Section 14 provides that a lessor who commits any act in violation of that section (including interference "with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises") shall "be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.” Nowhere is there any indication in § 14 that each rental period should be considered separately in determining damages. Section 14 allows a minimum recovery of three months’ rent as an incentive to the pursuit of relief where the actual and consequential damages are slight or are difficult to prove. When the actual damages exceed three months’ rent, however, § 14 plainly states that actual damages should be the measure of recovery.

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 201–204 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: The breach of quiet enjoyment described herein is independent of, and in addition to, any rights Plaintiff may have under related housing and consumer protection statutes designed to ensure safe and decent housing and to prevent unfair or deceptive practices by landlords, including but not limited to G.L. c. 239, § 8A (permitting tenants to assert counterclaims and defenses based on interference with quiet enjoyment) and G.L. c. 93A (unfair and deceptive acts in trade or commerce). See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 201–204 (1979); Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151, 158–163 (1985).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with the common-law warranty of habitability and rent abatement, and it discusses G.L. c. 239, § 8A only as statutory background supporting a fault-free abatement remedy. It does not characterize breach of quiet enjoyment (or habitability) as an independent remedy in addition to statutory rights, nor did the tenant assert or the court analyze claims under c. 239, § 8A or c. 93A as separate causes of action. The case therefore does not stand for the specific proposition that the quiet enjoyment breach is independent of, and in addition to, those statutory remedies, even though it is broadly consistent with a tenant having multiple remedial avenues.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “When the tenant’s loss of heat occurred, G. L. c. 239, § 8A, permitted the tenant to withhold rent for Code violations only if ‘the owner . . . had not taken reasonable steps to remedy such conditions.’ … In 1977, the Legislature struck this provision. … As was the case in Hemingway, this statute provides for rent withholding, not rent abatement; but, as in Hemingway, we choose to permit a rent abatement as a matter of common law. We consider the result we reach here to be consistent not only with Hemingway, but also with the law dealing with breach of warranty and with express legislative policy.”

Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151, 158\u201.proposition: The breach of quiet enjoyment described herein is independent of, and in addition to, any rights Plaintiff may have under related housing and consumer protection statutes designed to ensure safe and decent housing and to prevent unfair or deceptive practices by landlords, including but not limited to G.L. c. 239, § 8A (permitting tenants to assert counterclaims and defenses based on interference with quiet enjoyment) and G.L. c. 93A (unfair and deceptive acts in trade or commerce). See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 201–204 (1979); Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151, 158–163 (1985).
Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151, 158\u201.support_reasoning: The cited portion of Leardi concerns (1) what constitutes an “injury” under G.L. c. 93A when a residential lease contains illegal clauses, and (2) on Allisan’s individual appeal, the level of “substantial” interference required to establish a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14. It does not discuss the relationship between a quiet enjoyment claim and other statutory remedies such as G.L. c. 239, § 8A or G.L. c. 93A, nor does it say that a quiet enjoyment breach is independent of those statutes. Thus, it does not affirm the proposition that the quiet enjoyment claim is an additional, independent remedy alongside the cited housing and consumer protection statutes.
Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151, 158\u201.relevant_excerpt: “Allisan joined the class action as a named plaintiff, and brought individual claims on the basis of interference with quiet enjoyment of the premises in violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14, and intentional infliction of emotional distress. … We disagree. ‘The phrase “quiet enjoyment” is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy ...’ (emphasis added). Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982). … The judge concluded that the conduct of the defendants’ agent did not substantially interfere with her right to quiet enjoyment, and this conclusion was not clearly erroneous.”}

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: The breach of quiet enjoyment described herein is independent of, and in addition to, any rights Plaintiff may have under related housing and consumer protection statutes designed to ensure safe and decent housing and to prevent unfair or deceptive practices by landlords, including but not limited to G.L. c. 239, § 8A (permitting tenants to assert counterclaims and defenses based on interference with quiet enjoyment) and G.L. c. 93A (unfair and deceptive acts in trade or commerce). See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 201–204 (1979); Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151, 158–163 (1985).

G.L. c. 93A.proposition: The breach of quiet enjoyment described herein is independent of, and in addition to, any rights Plaintiff may have under related housing and consumer protection statutes designed to ensure safe and decent housing and to prevent unfair or deceptive practices by landlords, including but not limited to G.L. c. 239, § 8A (permitting tenants to assert counterclaims and defenses based on interference with quiet enjoyment) and G.L. c. 93A (unfair and deceptive acts in trade or commerce). See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 201–204 (1979); Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151, 158–163 (1985).
